paper_title: Toxicity of the Commons: Curating Open-Source Pre-Training Data

sections.title: Abstract
sections.content: Open-source large language models are becoming increasingly available and popular among researchers and practitioners. While significant progress has been made on open-weight models, open training data is a practice yet to be adopted by the leading open-weight models creators. At the same time, there researchers are working to make language models safer. We propose a data curation pipeline to reduce harmful outputs by models trained on public domain data. There are unique challenges to working with public domain data, as these sources differ from web text in both form and content. Many sources are historical documents and are the result of Optical Character Recognition (OCR). Consequently, current state-of-the-art approaches to toxicity filtering are often infeasible or inappropriate for open data models. In this paper, we introduce a new fully open-source pipeline for open-data toxicity filtering. Our contributions are threefold. We create a custom training dataset, ToxicCommons, which is composed of texts which have been classified across five different dimensions (racial/origin-based, gender/sex-based, religious, ability-based discrimination, and violence). We use this dataset to train a custom classifier, Celadon, that can be used to detect toxic content in open data more efficiently at a larger scale. Finally, we describe the balanced approach to content filtration that optimizes safety filtering with respect to the filtered data available for training.

(cid:135) https://github.com/Pleias/toxic-commons ToxicCommons Model: Celadon Dataset: Introduction There are growing calls for transparency surrounding Large Language Models (LLM) (Bommasani et al., 2024). Legislation about safety and openness requirements such as EU AI Act (European Parliament, 2024) and Executive Order on the Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence (Executive Office of the President, 2023) are the first steps made by governments to ensure some form of LLM transparency. As emphasis on open models increases, developers open more parts of their training pipelines (Liu et al., 2023; Mehta et al., 2024; Faysse *equal contribution Work conducted while an intern at PleIAs. et al., 2024). The performance gap between open and closedweights models is closing fast: Metas Llama 3.1 405B Instruct (Meta Llama Team, 2024) and Mistrals Mistral Large 2 (Mistral, 2024) are both competitive when compared with frontier closed-source models (Chiang et al., 2024). Despite the increasing popularity and power of open-weight models, many modern open" models do not meet the requirements of the openness matrix (Liesenfeld and Dingemanse, 2024), where the openness of model takes into consideration not just model weights, but model-related artifacts such as training code and training data, documentation, and access to the model. Open training data is the dimension of openness that lags behind the most (Bommasani et al., 2024). Since some of the closed models are clearly trained on proprietary data that is scraped without the consent of the data creator, the lack of openness surrounding model training data poses significant ethical challenges (Longpre et al., 2024a). Open data presents unique challenges that this work tries to address. We hope that the provided data, pipeline and filtration principles will help to intensify work on open-data LLMs. Curating Public Domain Data Closed-source model developers consistently utilize copyrighted material in their training sets. OpenAI has been sued for using copyrighted newspaper data (Robertson, 2024), while Apple, Nvidia, and Anthropic have all been criticized by the YouTube community after being caught using copyrighted videos in their models (Gilbertson and Reisner, 2024). In contrast, the open-source community is pushing for greater transparency by adopting open-data practices. Key leaders have released not only open-weights models but training data as well, such as Dolma (Soldaini et al., 2024) used to train OLMo (Groeneveld et al., 2024) and the Pile (Gao et al., 2020) used to train the Pythia models (Biderman et al., 2023), inter alia. Upon inspection, these open corpora contain lot of implicit bias and stereotypes against certain gender, racial, ethnic, or disability groups (Bender et al., 2021; Dodge et al., 2021; Luccioni and Viviano, 2021). Unfortunately, the documentation of the open data curation pipelines is often lacking, and methods can be ad hoc or have little regard for the context of the data (Henderson et al., 2022). More resources need to be dedicated to curating and documenting the construction of these datasets in order to reduce disproportionate impacts on the most vulnerable groups at the margins of society (Birhane and Cummins, 2019; Birhane and Prabhu, 2021; Bender et al., 2021). Data curation, as well as other methods designed to address safety of open LLMs are to be understood in Bayesian sense: though it is highly unlikely that one could ever design safety tool that could enable non-toxic generation with probability one, every effort reduces the prior of the model for toxic behavior. Common Corpus1 was recently released. It is the largest public domain dataset for training language models. It comprises multilingual datasets, mostly coming from books and periodicals, and as such has great deal of cultural heritage content. In order to be in the public domain, many of these texts are historical. Most of the texts come from the 18th and 19th centuries, and some are much older. This kind of public domain data poses different set of challenges, relative to existing open datasets, which are often largely comprised of web text. While the toxicity of web text is well documented, (Bender et al., 2021; Groeneveld et al., 2024), we know much less about the risks posed by historical data. As societal norms, especially in the language surrounding minoritized and racialized groups, have changed substantially even over the last few decades. In order to use historical text data safely, we propose that it be classified and filtered. Existing toxicity classifiers are not well-suited to this task. Toxicity classifiers perform poorly on out-of-domain data (Adragna et al., 2020). Existing toxicity classifiers are trained to perform well on web text, which is unlike Common Corpus in style and content, due to text domain and genre, language change, and other factors. Toxicity classifiers have been shown to perform poorly on historical data (Borenstein et al., 2023). Additionally, much of the data in Common Corpus is collected via optical character recognition (OCR), which introduces noise into the data. OCR affects many NLP tasks (van Strien et al., 2020). Specifically, Borenstein et al. (2023) show that OCR errors lead to less accurate toxicity classification. We test an existing toxicity classifier on sample from Common Corpus. As it was trained to detect toxicity in contemporary web text, it generalizes very poorly to Common Corpus data. For example, we find that the toxicity classifier tends to assign higher toxicity when texts contain large amounts of capital letters. The classifier we tested also seems overly sensitive to words that may often appear in toxic or violent content, but are not necessarily toxic or harmful in many contexts, e.g. fear, army. We provide details and examples in Appendix Finally, there is less data available to developers in the public domain. While web text datasets are comprised of hundreds of gigabytes of data, historical data which has been digitized is much more sparse. Using ill-suited filtering methods may lead to removing large amounts of already limited data. We must not only identify problematic content 1https://huggingface.co/ collections/PleIAs/common-corpus65d46e3ea3980fdcd66a5613 with high accuracy, but we must also find way to transform data with low-levels of toxicity into useful data that contributes to safer open model. In this paper, we create classifier specific to Common Corpus in order to filter the data and prepare it for synthetic treatment. We also propose this as framework, which can be used in combination with our open and replicable methods to be adapted for any dataset. We show that it is possible to efficiently and effectively curate datasets that can help reduce unwanted model behaviors.

sections.title: Related Work
sections.content: Safety Guardrails Much of the work on creating safer language models focuses on post-training procedures. For models deployed through APIs and web interfaces, continual refinement and tuning both through parameter updates and also through system prompting and output moderation are common approaches. These methods have clear advantages over openweights models when it comes to trust and safety; however, this does not always translate to explicitly better performance in this respect, as even frontier versions of these models can be jail-broken with ease (Wei et al., 2023; Wu et al., 2024). There are also existing tools which can be deployed by developers of generative AI software to prevent AI-based software from violating safety policies. For example, Meta released Llama Guard 3, Prompt Guard, and Code Shield (Meta Llama Team, 2024) in order to help developers utilizing generative AI tools ensure that model outputs adhere to safety policies. Code Shield as tool can be deployed at inference time, providing obvious benefits to developers of closed-source software. Googles recent Shield Gemma (Zeng et al., 2024) builds upon previous success of Llama Guard 3, and helps the open-source community by advancing content moderation tools. However, when it comes to open-weights models, safety measures can only be implemented during pre-training and fine-tuning, and cannot be deployed in between the model and the user. Serving as an example of the difficulties open-weights model developers face, Llama Guard 3 was integrated into the Llama 3.1 release, and yet the results of this effort were quickly undone (Gade et al., 2023). As result, we argue that safety pipelines for open-source generative AI must start with thorough data filtering. Filtering Model Training Data Apart from post-training procedures, strategy for mitigating harmful model behaviors is dataset curation, often through filtering out harmful content in the training data. Most toxicity filtering on pre-training datasets falls into one of three categories: URL-based filtering, lexicon-based filtering, and classifier-based methods (Albalak et al., 2024). Datasets like FineWeb (Penedo et al., 2024) and the Llama 3 pre-training dataset (Meta Llama Team, 2024) filter out content that comes from URLs that are on blacklists, such as the UT1 URL Blacklist (Prigent, 2024). While this method may effectively reduce the amount of pornographic content, it does not directly address other kinds of toxic or offensive content that frequently appears in web text. It has also been shown that blocking pornographic content also reduce the amount of LGBTQ+ and African American English (AAE) text (Dodge et al., 2021; Zhou et al., 2021). This in turn may lead to lack of diversity or representation. Lexical filtering refers to removing documents that contain blacklisted words. This method was used to create the Colossal Clean Crawled Corpus (C4; Raffel et al. (2020)), which is used to train Gopher (Rae et al., 2021), Chinchilla (Hoffmann et al., 2022), T5 (Raffel et al., 2020), and more. In this case, any document that contained any word from the List of Dirty, Naughty, Obscene, and Otherwise Bad Words"2 was removed. The ROOTS corpus (Laurençon et al., 2022), which was used to train BLOOM (Scao et al., 2023) also filtered out texts that contained high ratios of words associated with pornographic spam. Aggressive filtering may lead to performance degradation (Henderson et al., 2022), because filters remove high quality data (Longpre et al., 2024b). This can occur especially when blacklisted words are filtered without considering their context, as some slurs or offensive terms may be acceptable in some specific contexts (Warner and Hirschberg, 2012). For example, slur or offensive term may be used in the discussion of that term without being toxic or offensive (Henderson et al., 2022). Additionally, some words in the commonly used bad words" lists have other, non-offensive uses. For example, we found high instances of bitch used in one dataset of historical newspapers, which always referred to female dogs or other animals. Finally, there are classifier-based methods for dataset filtering. When toxicity classifiers have been used to filter pretraining data, the classifiers have often been black-box, proprietary products. Gopher data was filtered using Google SafeSearch (Rae et al., 2021), which primarily filters out pornographic content (Monea, 2023). Palm 2 used fixed version of Perspective API3 to generate control tokens for subset of the data (Anil et al., 2023). The Perspective API specifically has been shown to be more accurate than heuristics or rule-based classifiers (Longpre et al., 2024b), but black-box APIs are not reproducible (Pozzobon et al., 2023). The Dolma dataset was filtered using FastText classifiers trained to identify text using the labels hate" and NSFW" (Soldaini et al., 2024). To the best of our knowledge, this work presents one of the only large-scale filtering procedures using open or reproducible methods for open pre-training data. There have been limited studies on the effects of these filters, however, more research is needed to understand how they affect model behavior (Albalak et al., 2024). Data Filtering Pipeline In this paper, we propose strategy of safety guardrails for open-data language modeling, especially well suited for issues specific to public domain data. We release classifier 2https://github.com/LDNOOBW/List-of-DirtyNaughty-Obscene-and-Otherwise-Bad-Words 3https://perspectiveapi.com/ and dataset specifically created for toxicity filtration in opensource datasets. In this section, we outline our strategy for the curation of the dataset and creation of the classifier: 1. Annotation Process: We use human annotations to guide the LLM annotation process, in order to allow for scalability of annotation while remaining true to the ground truth of the samples. 2. Toxicity Classifier: Using the LLM-generated annotations, we train classifier capable of identifying toxic content across four levels of severity (0, 1, 2, 3) in five different categories (race and origin-based, genderbased, ability-based, religion-based discrimination, as well as violence). 3. Synthetic Re-writing For Content Moderation: After classifying texts based on the above categories, we implement different content moderation policies depending on the severity of the problem. Texts with only low levels of toxicity are included with content warning, while the most egregious samples get re-written and reintroduced into the corpus in detoxified" form. We recognize that the dataset, composed of historical and post-OCR data, poses unique challenges to general opensource data, let alone closed-source data. It is our hope that not only can our dataset and classifier be used on similar types of data, but our process can be generalized to other use cases by the community at large. Dataset We chose 13 cultural heritage datasets from Common Corpus, which includes datasets from nine languages. All datasets are comprised of copyright-free, public domain text data. Several datasets were created from OCR data, so we applied OCR correction using OCRonos4 to reduce noise in the data. OCR correction does not remove all OCR errors, so there is still some noise from the digitization process in the data. Human Annotations In order to create baseline to compare the LLM annotations against, human-annotation of small subset of 15 chunks was necessary5. These annotations were on mix of lowand high-toxicity datasets to monitor overand under-sensitivity. The annotators independently annotated and scored ten different texts, before creating unified ground-truth dataset from these annotated examples to evaluate LLM performance. We identify five types of bias to train the classifier to detect, which are frequently identified in the literature: Race and origin-based bias: includes racism as well as bias against someones country or region of origin or immigration status, especially immigrant or refugee status (Zhang et al., 2023). Gender and sexuality-based bias: includes sexism and misogyny, homophobia, transphobia, and sexual harassment (Sosto and Barrón-Cedeño, 2024). Religious bias: any bias or stereotype based on someones religion. Ability bias: bias according to someones physical, mental, or intellectual ability or disability (Farrelly et al., 2023). Violence and abuse: overly graphic descriptions of violence, threats of violence, or calls or incitement of violence (Saha et al., 2023). The annotators rated each text on dimension of bias on scale from 0 to 3. This scale was used for two reasons: it is easily explainable, such that we can make clear distinctions between categories, and it should not introduce any further complexities into the classification process. Any scale with more than four classes would prove to be difficult to properly explain to language model. LLM annotators are most effective when decisions are left up to as little interpretation as possible, and we felt that by clearly defining these four categories, we would attain the most success. Many classifiers are either binary, toxic or not toxic, or on continuous scale between 0 and 1. Neither of these methods suit our task; binary scale cannot properly capture the nuances of our dataset, and continuous scale is impossible to curate using LLM annotators. The four categories for classifying each dimension of bias are provided below: 0: Text mentions stereotypes about particular group of people or acts of violence, but does so in an objective way; text does not promote biases against any group or acts of violence. 1: Text implies biased beliefs against group of people or implicitly makes suggestions of violent acts, but does not do so explicitly. 2: Text clearly expresses biased beliefs against group of people, but does not do so in an overly aggressive manner, nor does it actively promote the spread of such beliefs. 3: Text overtly promotes hatred towards or disenfranchisement of group of people or promotes the superiority of one group of people over another; text calls for violence against an individual or group of people; text persuasively describes stereotypes or biases against group of people or characteristics associated with particular group (especially groups according to race, sex, gender, origin, ability, or religion). As texts were rated, the annotators did not consider any slurs or offensive terms in their annotations to reflect the process of the LLM annotations. The intention was to develop an annotation process that would detect implicit bias but would not be overly sensitive to certain lexical items.

sections.title: LLM Annotations
sections.content: We tested three models and compared zero-shot and fewshot prompting strategies for the LLM annotations. We tested GPT-3.5, Claude 3 Haiku, and Llama 3.1. Claude was most likely to refuse to provide an annotation. Claude also tended to give higher ratings often giving score of 3 on given dimension, which often did not align with the human annotations. GPT-3.5 was more likely than the other models to underestimate the human toxicity scores. We found that Llama 3.1 was well-aligned with human annotations. Additionally Llama 3.1 is an open-weight model, which makes this procedure more easily replicable. We did not find that few-shot prompting improved the alignment of the model annotations with the gold human annotations. Fewshot prompting tended to make the models give higher toxicity ratings, even when not appropriate to do so. We report comparisons and examples in Appendix E. Using the human annotations as baseline, we refined prompt to generate scores and annotations on each of the five dimensions of bias. The prompt uses the same scale from 0 to 3 as for the human annotations. The prompt was designed to have relatively high bar for toxicity, so that only the most offensive content had score of 3 for given dimension. We report the prompt we developed in Appendix C. We provide examples of annotations for toxic text in Appendix F. Note that the content of the texts and annotations may be offensive or upsetting. We release the LLM-annotated dataset, ToxicCommons6, with 2M samples. We report the rates of each score above 0 for each dataset. Figure 1 shows the scores for the US Newspapers dataset. The scores for the other datasets are reported in Appendix D. We find that the dimension with the highest rates of scores above 0 is Violence. Llama 3.1, as well as other models we tested, were generally very sensitive to any description of violent events. For the other dimensions, we find that generally less than 5% of texts are assigned score above 0 for each of the other dimensions. 6https://huggingface.co/datasets/PleIAs/ 5We provide these annotations in full in Appendix B. Across all datasets, we found highest toxicity rates for the violence and abuse dimension, relative to other dimensions. When tested different models, we found that all models were the most sensitive to the violence dimension. Toxicity Classifier We use the LLM annotations to train Celadon7, our toxicity classifier. The model was trained on just over 640K samples of data taken from the LLM annotation dataset, and validated on around 133K samples. The entire LLM annotation dataset comprises 2 million samples across the different datasets; however, due to the overwhelming majority of non-toxic data in the data, we did not use the whole dataset. Table 2 shows the number of samples, per category, per class, for the training split. An additional challenge was the much smaller quantity of non-zero-score samples for the ability-based discrimination dimension. Had we downsampled the majority classes completely to match the minority classes, the classifier would not have been trained on data that was truly representative of the distribution of samples in Common Corpus. Instead, we chose to make the maximum number of not toxic samples (samples where the sum of toxicity scores was 0) equal to the sum of all of the samples with at least some toxicity (samples where the sum of toxicity scores was 1 or more). Additional training details are provided in Appendix G, including the score distribution for the validation and training sets. Training code is avail7https://huggingface.co/PleIAs/celadon 8https://github.com/Pleias/toxic-commons Evaluation Results Classifier performance was further tested on held-out sample of 133K LLM annotations. Tables 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 outline the test-set performance of the classifier on each of the various categories. We found very high performance according to precision, recall, F1, and accuracy metrics; however, we argue that these metrics are misleading for this task. Due to the low prevalence of ability-based discrimination, the classifier performs extremely well on all metrics by predicting the majority class (0) the most often. As result, we included weighted accuracy as an important metric for model evaluation, given the distribution of the scores across all four classes for each category. The classifier performs the best in terms of weighted accuracy for the violence category, yielding weighted accuracy of 74%. The model has lower values of precision, recall, F1, and accuracy for this category, relative tother. We argue this is an indicator of good model performance, as it suggests that the classifier is correctly predicting at or around the correct class most of the time. Specifically, we note the distribution of classifications per category. For religion-based toxicity, and violence, the distribution of guesses centers about the correct class. Critically, samples that are true 0s are likeliest to be predicted as 0, with 1 being next likeliest at much lower rate. True 1s are likeliest to be predicted 1s, then 0s, then 2s, 2s are likeliest to be predicted as 2s, 1s, then 3s, and 3s are likeliest to be predicted as 3s or 2s. This is an important feature of the classifier, as we aim not to be over-sentitive in the filtering of this dataset. Furthermore, the classifier consistently predicts one class lower than the true class as the second majority class, which signals that the classifier does not often to predict higher scores than is true. The purpose of the classifier is to quickly and efficiently identify samples of text which should be annotated by an expert LLM annotator, and for this task, it excels in its duties. sections.content: Table 7: Test Set Accuracy Measures: Precision, Recall, F1, Accuracy, and Weighted Accuracy (WA) 1. No Toxicity: total score of 0-3 with no individual category score exceeding 2. These texts either have no toxic content, or very low levels not warranting any further treatment. We allow some breathing room with scores of 2 for any overly-sensitive cases. 2. Mild Toxicity: total score of between 4 and 6, or total score of 3 where that score comes from 3 in single category. For lower score of 3, we require the sole contribution to come from single category, while higher scores indicate toxicity across multiple categories in significant manner. 3. Toxic Content: The sum of scores is 7 or greater. This text likely contains toxic content that requires scrutiny from an LLM annotator. The thresholds used to divide the data into these three categories reflect our desire to not over-correct texts in our dataset. As mentioned previously, over-correction is almost as detrimental to our work as under-correction. It is critical that the historical nature and context of the data be preserved as much as possible, and removing too much content would reduce many of the benefits of working with public domain and especially cultural heritage data. As result, we aimed to be more lenient with our thresholds, accounting for the fact that there are two potential vectors for over-sensitivity: the LLM annotations, and then the distilled classifier. These thresholds reflect deliberate decisions that we made as result of our specific task, but it is important to note that as we release this pipeline to the broader community, these thresholds will adjust depending on individual needs. The classifier acts as useful intermediary: the smaller architecture of the DeBERTa-v3-small model means that it is deployable at scale much more efficiently than LLM9. However, we reintroduce the LLM back into the pipeline for the final step of 9We found that Celadon is over 40 times faster than Llama for annotations. On an NVIDIA H100 GPU, it took 3.43 hours (205 minutes) to annotate 100k samples with Llama, and only 5 minutes the process, which annotating or re-writing texts which have been labeled as toxic. The classifier proves to be an incredible useful heuristic when it comes to identifying toxic text, however, we recognize due to the accuracy-efficiency tradeoff, it is not always accurate. As result, the re-introduction of the LLM annotator is critical part of the pipeline, both for annotating or re-writing text that is actually problematic, or to better contextualize text that isnt. Content Warning. The first LLM treatment for toxic data is to synthetically generate content warning for the text. The intention is to develop datasets that can help models to reason about harmful content and ideas. To do this, we use Llama 3.1. We wrote the initial prompt in English, and then translated it to the remaining languages, in order to ensure that the LLM annotator would not default to English for its annotations, and instead match the parent language of the original text. Were we to obtain results where the entirety of the content warnings were in English, we would not only introduce greater imbalance of English tokens into the dataset, but we would also artificially align content moderation outputs with the English language. Further, by utilizing Llama 3.1, we rely on its multilingual capabilities in order to better contextualize the texts in different languages. We provide the LLM annotator with the previously defined bias categories as well as their definitions. We then prompt it to create content warning that includes justification for why the content may be toxic, utilizing cultural, ethical, legal, or moral arguments. We also encourage it to state if the provided text is not toxic in any manner. In this vein, it is crucial that we do not provide the axes upon which the classifier has deemed the text toxic, so as to not skew the thoughts of the LLM annotator. Should it deem provided piece of text not toxic across any axis, this additional content warning will still be kept, as it provides additional alignment benefits for the final model. We report the prompts used for the content warning in Appendix H. Synthetic Re-writing. We follow similar process as with generating the content warnings to synthetically rewrite content that is extremely toxic. We writing the prompt in English and then translate it to the other languages. We also provide the LLM with the categories of bias and their definitions, and we prompt it to provide the re-written text, reworded in order to remove any traces of toxicity, while staying as authentic as possible to the original style, tone, context, and word choice of the provided text. We also ask it for list of changes made to the original text in order to better engineer annotations that adhere to the guidelines provided. As with the content warning, should the LLM decide that the provided text is not toxic across any of the categories, it will simply return the provided text, along with the reasoning that it is not toxic. The most interesting results from this process occur when the LLM annotator is fed truly toxic content, that contains no meaningful language that isnt part of representing toxic belief. In this case, the annotator will re-write the entire text in an anti-toxic manner. We report the prompts used for the synthetic re-writing with Celadon. This is significant speed-up, when considering annotating trillions of tokens of text. in Appendix I.

sections.title: Discussion and Conclusion
sections.content: Due to the nature of public domain data for LLM training that contrasts with closed data, we demonstrate need to create new approach that properly balances the desire to better align language models trained with the dataset with the importance to preserve the inherent properties of the text data. One approach is to filter out everything that is at all toxic. This is possible to do with larger web-based or otherwise open but not public domain data, and still remain with enough tokens to train an LLM. However, we are more limited in the curation of open and public domain data that is also relatively free of harmful content. We propose computeand data-efficient approach that preserves the vast majority of the data, while still mitigating harms. We release this pipeline, our annotated dataset, the classifier, as well as the prompts used for synthetic data generation from toxic text sources. To our knowledge, this pipeline represents the an effective method of handling toxic content in the pre-training phase on public domain data, and has the potential for broader applications across the open source AI community.

sections.title: Limitations
sections.content: We recognize that our methods come with their limitations. First, our corpus is not that linguistically diverse, given that we use mostly Western European languages. Even further, there are major differences in terms of the amount of resources available for the different languages offensive word lists, data available, and benchmarks are all lacking even for our relatively popular languages. Second, past our initial human-annotated data, we were financially incapable of paying human annotators to verify all of the annotations. Current state-of-the-art for this type of data curation often uses human annotators or verifiers in order to ensure the soundness of the training labels. While this potentially could improve accuracy, it also exposes humans to toxic text that is taxing to work with and difficult to read. By utilizing LLMs for the majority of the annotation process, we remove any human exposure to this content, with the risk of slightly less accurate annotations. Finally, in releasing our dataset to the public, we are knowingly publishing some content which is toxic and harmful in nature. We acknowledge that there are certain individuals who may use the data in our dataset to perpetuate bias across any of the five toxicity categories outlined in our paper, but as staunch proponents of full transparency and openness, we firmly believe that the greater benefits to the community that come from applied use cases will outweigh the costs of this decision.
